Department of Sustainable Fuels and Green Chemistry University of Chemistry and Technology Technická 5 Prague 6 166 28 Czech Republic Graphical abstract Anisole is a model molecule for studying hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin-derived oxygenates. Here we elucidate its HDO pathway over 10 % Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Adsorption experiments showed that anisole is adsorbed on the acidic sites of the Al2O3. Anisole adsorption at 200–300 °C is reactive in nature, and results in its demethylation. The catalyst was tested at 100–300 °C, 5–40 bar H2 pressure. Conversion of 78 % was obtained at 5 bar and 300 °C, restricted by hydrogenation-dehydrogenation equilibrium. HDO mainly starts through the ring-hydrogenation pathway. This is followed by demethoxylation beyond 180 °C. At 5–12 bar, cyclohexane dehydrogenates to benzene. This was confirmed by conducting an HDO experiment with methoxycyclohexane. At lower pressure deoxygenation is favored; and demethylation is accompanied with methylation of the aromatic ring, for temperature >260 °C. Investigation of the initial reaction stages showed that anisole HDO on Ni/Al2O3 catalyst proceeds via two independent pathways i.e., reactive adsorption/(de)methylation and aromatic ring hydrogenation. Keywords Anisole HDO Reaction pathway Demethoxylation Demethylation Methylation Dehydrogenation Reactive adsorption Ni/Al2O3 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Investigations on alternative fuels have led to the valorization of various plant-based molecules like lignin and cellulose. Lignin comprises about 30 % of biomass and is a naturally occurring polymer of oxygen-containing aromatic monomers [1–3]. The recent focus on the utilization of lignin as a sustainable source of biofuels and useful chemicals is gaining prominence [4–6]. Depolymerization of lignin is done through methods like thermal processes (e.g. slow and fast pyrolysis) [7], hydrothermal liquefaction processes [8], biological depolymerization [9], and chemical depolymerization [10]. These processes result in aromatic oxygenates like guaiacol, syringol, coniferyl alcohol, etc. Further valorization of these molecules may be done by catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), which results in compounds like benzene, cyclohexane, toluene, and phenol [11–14], as key building blocks for biofuels and petrochemicals synthesis. The primary objective is to remove oxygen from aromatic oxygenates, thereby increasing their fuel/petrochemical value [13]. A study showed that the blending of untreated lignin-derived oxygenates with petrol has resulted in a decrease in anti-knock quality, decreased volatility, and increased viscosity of the fuel [15]. A major challenge in the hydrodeoxygenation process of phenolic compounds is to remove oxygen without hydrogenating the aromatic ring. This reduces hydrogen consumption and produces a gasoline blending stock with better anti-knock quality [15]. Apart from the removal of oxygen, extensive research has focused on trans-alkylation reactions during the HDO process, attributed mainly to Brønsted acidic sites [16], which is important to reduce the loss of carbon from the feedstock [17–19]. Although much attention has been devoted to understanding the role of catalyst active sites, efforts in predicting the reaction pathway, and studying the effect of process parameters on the product distribution are lacking [20]. Anisole is a commonly used model molecule for studying HDO of lignin-derived aromatics, as it is the smallest molecule having a methoxy group attached to the benzene ring [21]. Researchers like Jin et al. [22], Yusuf et al. [23], and Khromova et al. [24] have carried out anisole HDO in batch reactors over alumina and silica-supported nickel catalysts under the pressure in the range of 30 to 60 bar. They have observed that the reaction initiates with aromatic hydrogenation followed by deoxygenation through demethylation and dehydration; during which they have reported only traces of aromatic compounds like benzene and phenol. However, they did not explain the origin of these compounds The existing literature widely reports on the role of active sites in anisole HDO reactions like trans-methylation [17,25,26], demethylation [27,28], dehydration [29], and direct-deoxygenation [30–32]. In these studies, a comparison of the product distribution obtained over different catalysts was used to propose reaction routes, without considering the effect of process conditions that may drastically alter the product distribution. For example, the work of He et al. [33] and Rensel et al. [34] have shown that the cleavage of aryl-oxygen bond in 2-phenyl ethyl phenyl ether and phenol, respectively, depends on the H2 pressure. Also, equilibrium constraints dictate that the distribution of the product components may greatly vary based on temperature, pressure, and the concentration of other reacting species. The strategies to study the reaction pathway adopted by Nei and Resasco [35], and Sun et al. [36] have shown the significance of dehydrogenation reactions by obtaining aromatic compounds from HDO of the saturated cyclic intermediate products. This enabled them to propose a comprehensive reaction pathway for m-cresol HDO. In our experiments, we have also observed how the reversible nature of the aromatic ring hydrogenation reaction may result in the formation of benzene from cyclohexane in the product mixture of anisole HDO, which was further corroborated by theoretical calculations. The work of Peters et al. [26] studied guaiacol HDO over nickel-based catalysts at varying catalyst-to-guaiacol feed-rate ratios (weight hourly space velocity WHSV) to reveal that the reaction initiates first through trans-alkylation reactions, due to the increase in selectivity of alkylated products at higher WHSV. A similar approach was also taken by Xu et al. [37] for anisole HDO over zeolite-based catalysts. However, these studies focused mainly only on one reaction pathway for the initiation of HDO; and do not show how the different reaction routes proceed further, especially under a wide range of temperature and pressure, which our present study investigates. The reaction pathway may be fully unveiled when the understanding of the effect of temperature and pressure variations is combined with the study of reaction equilibrium. Additionally, the need for studying the reactive nature of anisole adsorption on Ni/Al2O3 catalytic surface remains. This article gives new insights into the activity of a commonly used Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, where the reactions involved in anisole HDO were distinctively associated with its reactive adsorption and hydrogenation. These reactions were found to be temperature-dependent during adsorption studies, which was reflected well in the catalytic data where the catalyst was tested under continuous flow conditions to reveal a temperature-dependent reaction pathway. Although several researchers have proposed specific reaction pathways of anisole transformation, our study is much broader, in a way that we have distinctively identified the active sites responsible for (de)methylation and deoxygenation reactions, and how they are affected by process conditions as well as thermodynamic constraints. As mentioned before, trace components of the reaction mixture are often neglected. Our study shows that these trace components play a crucial role in deciphering the origin of the major products. This article also shows how the product distribution of anisole HDO at higher pressure is greatly different from that at lower pressure. This was due to the competitive consumption of anisole by hydrogenation and reactive adsorption pathways, and the influence of thermodynamics. Experiments were conducted to unravel the origin of these products. The reaction was carried out at a lower catalytic contact time which resulted in insights into the initial stages of the reaction. This article reports the effect of reaction equilibrium in deciding the maximum possible anisole conversion as well as the product distribution, that is dominant at lower H2 pressure. This is done by thermodynamic calculations and performing HDO experiments with the reaction intermediates. Finally, this article proposes a robust reaction pathway and identifies optimal reaction conditions for aromatics production with respect to future biofuels production. 2 Materials and method Ni/Al2O3 catalyst with 10 wt% loading of Ni was prepared by wet impregnation method using nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·3H2O, Carl Roth Germany) precursor and alumina (ɣ-Al2O3) granules (mesh 300/155, Sasol Germany) as support. After impregnation, the material was dried at 120 °C for 5 h and calcined at 350 °C for 5 h in air. An important aspect of Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is its surface chemistry, namely the presence of Ni species like NiO and NiAl2O4. For comparative characterization studies, NiO and NiAl2O4 (spinel) were used. NiO was prepared by calcination of nickel nitrate at 350 °C for 5 h. For the preparation of NiAl2O4, the method described by Cesteros et al, 2000 [38] was followed. In brief, 0.17 M nickel nitrate and 0.34 M aluminum nitrate (Lach-Ner Czech Republic) were co-precipitated by the slow addition of 1 M solution of ammonium hydroxide (Lach-Ner Czech Republic) solution. The precipitate was filtered, dried, and calcined at 700 °C. The materials were characterized using XRF, XRD, XPS, N2-BET, H2-TPR, H2-pulse chemisorption and NH3-TPD. A detailed description of instrumentation and methods is provided in section S1.1. of the supplementary material. Anisole adsorption and desorption studies were carried out in a tubular quartz flow reactor, with FID for monitoring the outlet-stream composition. A detailed description of the setup and data evaluation is provided in section S1.2. Anisole adsorption (breakthrough curve) was performed at 36 °C to determine the adsorption capacity of the reduced catalyst and neat support. This was followed by desorption studies under heating in different atmospheres (inert or reducing atmosphere) to investigate the types of anisole adsorption sites and possible hydrogenolysis reaction of the adsorbed anisole. To understand anisole adsorption mode at different reaction temperatures, anisole adsorption at elevated temperatures (above 100 °C) was performed showing that in this case adsorption is reactive in nature and therefore the experiment was called reactive adsorption. To evaluate the reaction of hydrogen with the residual adsorbed products of anisole reactive adsorption at that temperature (isothermal hydrogenation) was performed. Anisole (Sigma-Aldrich, for synthesis, purity ≥ 99 %) was used as a model compound to study Ni/Al2O3 hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) performance. Also, methoxycyclohexane (synthesized in-lab) and cyclohexanol (Penta s.r.o, Czech Republic), as intermediate products of the anisole HDO, were used as feedstock to investigate the reaction pathways. No solvent was used in the HDO experiments with anisole and methoxycyclohexane. However, decalin (Penta s.r.o, Czech Republic) was used as a solvent for dissolving cyclohexanol and phenol. A detailed description of the flow-reactor unit and experimental procedure is provided in section S1.3. Catalyst testing of the Ni/Al2O3 was performed in a wide range of reaction temperatures (100–300 °C) and hydrogen (SIAD Czech spol. s.r.o) pressures (5–40 bar). Weight hourly space velocity (WHSV, 30–180 h−1) defined as the ratio of the mass flowrate of anisole (liquid feed) to the weight of the catalyst was maintained by a specific liquid feed rate with respect to the weight of the catalyst (0.1–0.4 g catalyst loading). The H2/feed ratio was kept as 1660 (v/v), unless specified otherwise. The liquid products were collected in 2 ml vials, while gaseous samples were collected in Flex–Foil plus sample bags. The liquid and gaseous samples were analyzed by GC-FID as discussed in section S1.4. Calculations of conversions and selectivities were done by tracking the molar quantities of the aromatic ring present in anisole. A component mass balance between the liquid and gas phases resulted in the evaluation of the molar composition of the reaction product (liquid and gaseous combined). This was used to evaluate conversion (equation (1) ) and selectivity (equation (2) ). An experimental error of 3.8–5.2 % was found in the repeated set of experiments. (1) A n s i o l e c o n v e r s i o n , % = 100 × ∑ m o l e s o f p r o d u c t s o f a n i s o l e H D O m o l e s o f a n i s o l e f e e d (2) S e l e c t i v i t y , % = 100 × m o l e s o f a p r o d u c t c o m p o u n d ∑ m o l e s o f p r o d u c t s o f a n i s o l e H D O Thermodynamic equilibrium considerations were obtained through the data generated from Aspen plus (version 12.1) simulation studies, and were used to understand thermodynamic constraints involving reaction conversions and product distributions. Peng Robinson equation of states was implemented for rigorous investigation of reaction equilibrium, based on Gibbs free energy minimization. Reaction temperature was considered as the manipulation variable in the range of 100–300 °C, with increment steps of 10 °C. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization The Ni content of the catalyst was confirmed by XRF and ICP-OES to be 9.9 ± 0.15 and 9.6 ± 0.3 wt% of Ni, respectively. Textural properties were investigated using N2-physisorption, which showed the catalyst to be mesoporous in nature (refer Figure S1 a); having a specific surface area of 138 m2/g and well-defined cylindrical pores with an average diameter of 6–8 nm ( Figure S1 b). The phase composition analysis by XRD ( Figure S2 ) has shown the presence of a mixture of Al2O3, NiO, and spinel-like structures which was further supported by XPS analysis ( Figure S3 ). Detailed discussion on these characterization studies has been provided in section S2 of the supplementary material. The reduction profile of the Ni/Al2O3 (Fig. 1 ) indicates that the catalyst contains three kinds of nickel species: dispersed and weakly-interacting NiO, NiAl2O4, and predominately Ni interacting with the support, which may be considered as non-stoichiometric nickel aluminate [39]. This agrees well with the results of XRD and XPS. The small peak at 250 °C belongs to the reduction of residual nickel nitrates. The reduction degree of the sample reduced at 480 °C is only 60 %, while the sample reduced at 800 °C is fully reduced (Table 1 ). H2-pulse chemisorption has shown that the Ni surface area of the reduced catalyst was 5 m2/gsample. When H2-TPD was performed on the reduced catalyst two desorption peak maxima were found at 400 and 500 °C (refer Figure S4 a). The details of these results are also discussed in section S2 of the supplementary material. Since the acidic properties are often associated with the deoxygenation ability of HDO catalysts [40], the acidity was evaluated by NH3-TPD. Only molecular adsorption of ammonia was observed on alumina support and unreduced catalyst (Fig. 2 a and b) whereas, ammonia was adsorbed dissociatively on the reduced Ni sites (Fig. 2 c) resulting in N2 and H2 evolution during temperature increase. H2 was desorbed in two peaks, while N2 was desorbed only in one peak. Since the desorption was terminated at 480 °C and the H2 signal did not fall to zero, it is probable based on the observation from H2-TPD signal that some hydrogen was still stored on the catalyst surface. This hypothesis is also supported by the molar ratio of H2/N2 evolved being 2, which is below the stoichiometry of ammonia decomposition (should be 3). The number of adsorbed ammonia (without subsequent dissociation) is the same for the reduced Ni/Al2O3 as well as non-reduced Ni/Al2O3 (Table 2 ). The value is lower in comparison with neat Al2O3 (75 % of the original value) because part of the surface is covered by Ni in oxidic (non-reduced Ni/Al2O3) or reduced form (Ni/Al2O3). It means that molecular (undissociated) ammonia adsorbed exclusively on the alumina support, i.e. there was no molecular ammonia adsorbed on Ni oxides. However, Ni species responsible for NH3 dissociative adsorption can be also understood as Lewis acid sites and their amount can be calculated from the amount of evolved nitrogen keeping in mind ammonia decomposition stoichiometry (from two moles of NH3 one mole of N2 can be formed). Therefore, the sample containing reduced nickel consists of two different acid sites (denoted as A and B in Table 2), but their total amount is equal to that of unmodified alumina support (Table 2). Acid strength distribution is very similar for the catalyst and the alumina support. The NH3 profile shows a desorption peak in the whole tested temperature range of 100–––480 °C pointing to the presence of weak and medium acid sites [41]. 3.2 Anisole adsorption, desorption, and surface reaction with hydrogen The total surface capacity for anisole adsorption was evaluated by performing breakthrough curve measurements for the neat alumina support (Fig. 3 a) and for the reduced Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 3 b). Alumina support can accommodate 545 ± 12 μmol/g of anisole, while Ni/Al2O3 has a slightly lower (444 ± 12 μmol/g) adsorption capacity. A slightly higher value (645 μmol/g) was obtained by Popov et al. [42], who studied the adsorption of phenolic molecules on oxidic catalysts by IR spectrometry, however, they used alumina with a higher surface area (292 m2/g). The decrease in anisole adsorption capacity of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is almost equal to the decrease in its acidity (type A) as indicated in Table 2. This comparison provides evidence that anisole is almost exclusively adsorbed on the acid sites provided by the alumina support (indicated as site A in Table 2). Adsorption measurements at 36 °C were followed by desorption studies in N2 i.e., anisole-TPD (point 1 in Table 3 ), and in H2 i.e., TPSR (point 2 in Table 3). Both experiments were carried out at a temperature range of 36–480 °C as shown in Fig. 4 . It was found that anisole adsorption on the catalyst was strong. As a result, only a small amount of weakly adsorbed anisole was desorbed. This desorption was completed at about 150 °C (Fig. 4). Nevertheless, TPSR showed that anisole undergoes demethoxylation to benzene at temperatures 130–150 °C in the presence of H2 (point 2, Table 3). This suggests that such a temperature is essential for anisole hydrogenolysis. Strong adsorption of phenolics on different supported metallic nanoparticles in HDO catalysts was suggested by Gueddida [43] based on their Ab initio calculations. According to Popov et al. [42], anisole is adsorbed on alumina at room temperature in two different ways, i.e., weakly adsorbed species and coordinated species on Lewis sites, which decompose with an increase in temperature and the cleavage of PhO-CH3 bond proceeds around 200 °C, while CH3 migrates to the surface oxygen atoms. To understand the reactive behavior of the adsorption of anisole, it was necessary to conduct similar adsorption experiments at various temperatures (100, 200, 300 °C), in a N2 environment (see Table 4 ). In these studies, adsorption at different temperatures (100, 200, 300 °C) was followed by cleaning the surface with N2 at the same temperature. It was found that anisole undergoes reactive adsorption at temperatures above 100 °C. These reactions were not observed when anisole was desorbed in N2 at similar temperatures during TPD measurements, suggesting that these reactions can be attributed to the adsorption process of anisole at higher temperatures. The reactions consisted of demethylation of anisole to phenol. In addition, simultaneous methylation of anisole/phenol was observed (reaction scheme in Table 4). The molecules underwent further (de)methylation to give to dimethylphenol. With the increase in temperature from 200 to 300 °C, the concentration of the products was found to increase. A blank experiment was conducted with Al2O3, at 300 °C (Fig. 5 ). It was found that the products were similar to those found with Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 6 ). These experiments provide sufficient evidence that Al2O3 is not only responsible for the adsorption of anisole but also responsible for (de)methylation reactions, which occur at temperatures above 200 °C. These adsorption studies were followed by passing 10 % H2/Ar. In the presence of H2, deoxygenation reactions were observed. When anisole is adsorbed at 36 °C, it is directly deoxygenated to benzene (point 2 of Table 3). However, when it is absorbed at a temperature greater than 100 °C, the products of reactive adsorption and unreacted anisole get deoxygenated together (Fig. 7 ). Deoxygenation reaction in the presence of H2 (Table 5 ) occurs either through dehydration of phenol/methyl phenol to yield benzene/toluene or through demethoxylation of anisole or methyl anisole to produce benzene or toluene respectively. In continuation of the blank experiment with neat Al2O3 support, no reaction was found to occur after the contact of adsorbed anisole species with hydrogen at 300 °C. This was due to the lack of dissociated hydrogen in the absence of nickel. Thus, it was clear that nickel sites are responsible for hydrogenation-deoxygenation reactions, which agrees with the literature [19,20,44]. From these adsorption studies, it is evident that anisole HDO pathway over Ni/Al2O3 catalyst may occur through different and possibly independent pathways due to the different roles played by Ni and alumina support. The reaction pathway was also found to be temperature-dependent. The subsequent sections of the article are dedicated to the investigation of the reaction pathways and their dependence on process conditions. 3.3 Catalyst testing 3.3.1 Anisole HDO: Effect of temperature and pressure To understand the nature of the hydrodeoxygenation of anisole over Ni/Al2O3 catalyst and its product distribution, HDO experiments were performed in a wide range of reaction conditions (100–300 °C, WHSV 30 h−1 and pressure 5, 20, and 40 bar). The effect of the increasing reaction temperature together with hydrogen pressure positively influenced anisole conversion (Fig. 8 a). It was found that complete conversion of anisole can be achieved at 200 °C for the pressure above 20 bar, however at lower hydrogen pressure (5 bar) only 75–80 % conversion could be achieved despite the further increased reaction temperature. The limitation to attain complete conversion may be explained by Fig. 8 b, which shows that the maximum attainable anisole conversion to methoxycyclohexane is limited by the anisole-methoxycyclohexane reaction equilibrium. When equilibrium calculations were done with H2/anisole of 1660/1 (v/v) or 8/1 M ratio in the feed, the maximum anisole conversion (i.e., considering all the hydrogen present is available for hydrogenation and the time of contact is sufficient for attaining equilibrium) was found to be the lowest at 5 bar. It reached 95 % at 270 °C and 68 % at 300 °C as shown in Fig. 8 b. However, during HDO experiments at 300 °C, 78 % anisole conversion was obtained indicating that further deoxygenation of methoxycyclohexane to cyclohexane over-rides the hydrogenation-dehydrogenation equilibrium constraint (refer to section S6). A higher value of the maximum conversion is also due to the presence of an additional pathway of anisole consumption other than the path initiating with hydrogenation of the aromatic ring. The growth in the reaction pressure allowed to lower the reaction temperature at which a given anisole conversion was achieved. For example, 45 % anisole conversion could be achieved at 180 °C for 5 bar, 150 °C for 20 bar, and 130 °C for 40 bar. Methoxycyclohexane was identified as the major product (90–95 %) formed in the lower temperature range (100–180 °C) indicating that the reaction initiates mainly with hydrogenation of the aromatic ring and was found to be more favorable at higher reaction pressure. Starting from 180 °C, deoxygenation of methoxycyclohexane takes place with further cyclohexane formation, which is visible from the selectivities for methoxycyclohexane (Fig. 8 c) and cyclohexane (Fig. 8 d). Studies in section 3.2 have shown that above 100 °C, deoxygenation occurred through direct demethoxylation. However, in those studies, ring hydrogenation was not observed due to lower H2 partial pressure. Also, there is a possibility that methoxycyclohexane may be converted first to cyclohexanol and then to cyclohexane. This is investigated in section 3.3.4 . It was observed that the cleavage of the O-cyclohexyl bond is favorable at lower pressures, which results in almost complete deoxygenation of methoxycyclohexane possible at lower temperatures (220 vs 260 vs 280 °C for 5, 20, and 40 bar, respectively) refer to Fig. 8 c. Additionally, Fig. 8 d depicts that cyclohexane selectivity at 5 bar reached its maximum at about 220 °C and decreased at temperatures above 220 °C. This was due to the dehydrogenation of cyclohexane to benzene as shown in Fig. 8 e. The possibility of the change in catalyst selectivity from ring-hydrogenation reaction towards direct-deoxygenation of anisole to benzene, at high temperature and low pressure may be ruled out, as such a change was not observed in adsorption studies ( section 3.2 .). Further evidence of the generation of benzene by dehydrogenation of cyclohexane was found during HDO of methoxycyclohexane as explained in section 3.3.4 . Cyclohexanol was found among the products (Fig. 8 f) in the liquid phase which is an indication of the second reaction pathway of the anisole HDO through the demethylation of anisole with further hydrogenation of the aromatic ring towards cyclohexanol, during reactive adsorption of anisole (see section 3.2 .). The origin of cyclohexanol is further explained in section 3.3.4 . Fig. 8 f also depicts that the maximum selectivity towards cyclohexanol occurs at 200, 240, and 270 °C, for the reaction pressure of 5, 20, and 40 bar, respectively. This indicates that anisole is consumed competitively by both the ring hydrogenation pathway and reactive adsorption. As the temperature increases the rate of consumption through both these routes increases. However, as pressure increases, the ring hydrogenation route becomes predominant and the peak for cyclohexanol selectivity is shifted to higher temperatures. It is also evident that the maximum selectivity towards cyclohexanol at 5 bar is lower than that at 20 and 40 bar. This is due to the occurrence of methylation of the aromatic ring during reactive adsorption, which is prevalent at lower pressure (pressure dependence is further explained in section 3.3.2 .). The complex nature of the product distribution may be visualized by 2D-GC analysis of the HDO product at 5 bar, 270 °C ( Figure S11 ). A trace amount (0.05–0.12 % selectivity) of phenol was observed only at 5 bar, which suggests that cyclohexanol may be formed by ring hydrogenation of phenol. Generally, we can state that the favorability of the second reaction pathway starting with the demethylation of anisole increases with increased reaction temperature (Fig. 8 f). This is also suggested by the adsorption studies (see Table 4). In the case of reaction at 20 and 40 bar, ring hydrogenation is much faster and the methyl group on the catalyst surface may be hydrogenated to gas phase alkanes (C1-C4). 3.3.2 Effect of liquid to vapor phase transition on anisole HDO The effect of the phase (liquid or vapor) of the reaction mixture on conversion and product distribution has been studied for the H2 pressure of 8 and 12 bar in a wide range of reaction temperatures (180–300 °C), see Fig. 9 a-h. The results were compared with those at 5 bar. The blue, red, and green vertical lines were used to indicate the transition between liquid and gaseous phases at 5, 8, and 12 bar respectively in Fig. 9 a-h. The boiling points of anisole at different pressures were calculated using an online tool that can be found in ref. [45]. The smooth profiles indicate that the reaction pathway is indifferent toward the phase of the reactant. However, higher reaction pressure promoted anisole conversion (Fig. 9 a) where at 12 bar conversion reached above 97 %, but the maximum conversion for 5 and 8 bar was about 80 %. Fig. 9 b shows that methoxycyclohexane selectivity abruptly decreases from 80 % to about 20 %, 12 %, and 4 % for 12, 8, and 5 bar pressure respectively at 220 °C, while cyclohexane selectivity increases (Fig. 9 c). The drop is more evident at 5 bar because at lower pressures hydrogenation of the aromatic ring is slower and reactive adsorption (i.e., (de)methylation) is more prominent. This also helps explain the appearance of more methylated species at 5 bar (see Fig. 9 e and f). Further temperature rise is accompanied by the dehydrogenation of cyclohexane resulting in the formation of benzene (Fig. 9 d). Additionally, methylation of anisole (Fig. 9 e and f) is also seen above 260 °C. As explained before, the methylation reactions were found to strongly depend on the hydrogen pressure with the selectivity of methylated products decreasing as pressure increased from 5 to 12 bar and even disappearing for the higher pressures. The ramp-up cyclohexanol formation (Fig. 9 g) with maxima at 215–220 °C demonstrates the intensification of demethylation reactions, with further deoxygenation towards cyclohexane/benzene. Experiments also suggested that a small amount of anisole may condense with phenol, during demethylation reaction via the loss of methanol (Fig. 9 h). Cyclohexanol/phenol molecules may also lose water to undergo self-condensation. The work of Teles et al. [46] shows that biphenolic compounds may also be produced from the reaction between cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone (formed as an intermediate of phenol hydrogenation). These reactions were found to be uninfluenced by variations in temperature. Anisole HDO is found to be greatly affected by the reaction temperature and pressure. Here, at lower reaction pressure, myriads of components are observed (see Figure S8 ) that are not typical products for the higher pressure HDO, demonstrating the complexity of the reaction under low pressure due to the competitive consumption of anisole by ring hydrogenation and (de)methylation reactions. Thus, to shed light on the reaction pathways, the next section is dedicated to outlining the initial steps at 5 bar H2 pressure by reducing the contact time of the feedstock with the catalyst. 3.3.3 Catalyst stability test and the effect of WHSV The progression of a catalytic reaction is easily understood when the yield of the product components is expressed in terms of conversion. The complex nature of anisole HDO and its strong dependence on reaction temperature and pressure necessitates the generation of such data at a single reaction temperature and pressure To shed light on the initiation of ring hydrogenation and (de)methylation pathways, the reaction condition of 270 °C and 5 bar pressure has been chosen, where these reactions are most prevalent. This was achieved by progressively decreasing the contact time, i.e., increasing the WHSV. As WHSV was increased, lower anisole conversion was obtained, which also made the visualization of the initial steps of the reaction possible. Fig. 10 a shows that average anisole conversion of 69.2 %, 48.7 %, 19.7 %, and 15.4 % was achieved for WHSV 30, 60, 120, and 180 h−1 respectively. When the reaction was carried out at WHSV 30 h−1, the product was mainly composed of cyclohexane, benzene, methylated deoxygenated, and methylated un-deoxygenated products. Their selectivities were about 30 %, 60 %, 4.5 % and 3 % respectively (Fig. 10 b). About 1 % each of cyclohexanol and methoxycyclohexane were also seen, along with trace amounts of phenol. Selectivity of cyclohexane and benzene decreased from 60 % and 30 % to 48 % and 23 % respectively, when WHSV was increased from 30 to 180 h−1 (see Fig. 10 b and S7a-c in Section S4). However, the selectivities towards the previously mentioned trace components like phenol and methyl un-deoxygenated products increased to about 10 %. The increase in selectivities was observed only at higher WHSV. Figure S10 c shows that the data is consistent throughout the time on stream of 24 h. When we compare product yields, Fig. 10 c shows that the yield of phenol decreases with the increase in anisole conversion, whereas, the yield of methoxycyclohexane and methylated-un-deoxygenated products remains constant. As the yield of phenol, methoxycyclohexane, and methylated un-deoxygenated products do not increase with the increase in anisole conversion from 15-69 %, it may be concluded that they are formed directly from anisole at an earlier stage of the reaction. As the reaction progresses these products are further converted, which prevents their yield from increasing. On the other hand, the yield of products like cyclohexane or benzene (shown in Fig. 10 d) increases with anisole conversion. This clearly shows that these compounds are formed at a later stage of the reaction from their precursors. These results further support the conclusion that anisole is consumed by both ring hydrogenation (producing methoxycyclohexane as a primary product) and reactive adsorption pathway (affording phenol and methylated un-deoxygenated products). Also, benzene is not formed through the direct demethoxylation of anisole, but rather through cyclohexane dehydrogenation. Additionally, a comparison between the yield of methylated deoxygenated products and methylated un-deoxygenated products (in Fig. 10 c) suggests that methylation reactions occur prior to the deoxygenation of methylated compounds (like methyl anisole and methyl phenol). Methanol produced during demethoxylation of methoxycyclohexane may give rise to reactive surface methoxide species [47], which further undergo hydrogenation reactions. The products in the gas-phase were found to be methanol, methane-ethane (0.5–3.3 g/h, measured together), propane (0.03–0.06 g/h), butane (0.8–2.8 g/h), benzene (0.8–1.0 g/h) and cyclohexane (2,8–7.7 g/h). The C1-C4 hydrocarbons may come from a range of chemical reactions, including the demethylation of anisole (methane formation), methanation reactions over Ni (methane as well as C2-C4 hydrocarbons), or cracking reactions over acid sites. The measured values correspond to experiments at WHSV 180 and 30 h−1 respectively. The methoxide intermediates originating from both ring-hydrogenation and (de)methylation pathways may also participate in methylation of the aromatic ring, apart from forming C1-C4 hydrocarbons. Additionally, CO and CO2 were also detected in GC-TCD analysis, which also provides a possibility that the C1-C4 hydrocarbons may originate from methanol via CO and CO2, in a reducing environment. The work of Schmider et al. [48] has shown that formation of methane from CO and CO2 is thermodynamically favored reaction for temperatures below 500 °C over Ni catalysts. The adsorption studies with methanol in section S3 also support this conclusion, as we have observed methane formation over reduced Ni/Al2O3 catalyst during reactive adsorption of methanol (adsorption at 300 °C was accompanied by evolution of CH4, CO, CO2 as well as H2) and its isothermal hydrogenation (only methane was observed). As mentioned in Section 2 , only benzene and cyclohexane were considered in the calculations for anisole conversion and product selectivity throughout the article. These experiments were carried out for a time on stream of 24 h which also provides information about the stability of the catalyst. It was found that for WHSV 30 and 60 h−1, the anisole conversion in the first 8 h TOS decreased and then remained stable. For WHSV 120 and 180 h−1, anisole conversion remained constant throughout the complete experiment. The overall drop in anisole conversion was about 16.9 % for both WHSV 30 h−1 and 60 h−1, while that for WHSV 120 h−1 and 180 h−1 was 5.7 and 2.6 % respectively. The carbon content of the spent catalyst was determined by CHNS analysis and was found to be in the range of 1.25–2.5 %. This low extent of deactivation can be ascribed to the reaction being carried out at a H2 pressure of 5 bar or higher over Ni/Al2O3. 3.3.4 Hydrodeoxygenation of reaction intermediates The deciphering of anisole reaction pathway requires a better understanding of dehydrogenation reactions and the origin of cyclohexanol in the reaction product. Despite the presence of the anisole demethylation step (phenol formation), cyclohexanol may also be formed by demethylation of methoxycyclohexane. To verify this hypothesis, reaction intermediates like methoxycyclohexane, phenol, and cyclohexanol were considered as feed for HDO over the 10 % Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. We have synthesized 98–99 % pure methoxycyclohexane, from anisole HDO over 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3, at 170 °C and 40 bar H2 pressure. The reaction product was then distilled under atmospheric pressure to remove unreacted anisole and produced cyclohexane. Methoxycyclohexane HDO was carried out over 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst at WHSV 26 h−1, temperature range of 160–270 °C and 5 bar pressure. Under these reaction conditions, methoxycyclohexane did not react till 200 °C. The primary products of methoxycyclohexane HDO were cyclohexane and benzene as shown in the reaction scheme of Fig. 11 . Traces of cyclohexene (selectivity of 0.3 % at 270 °C) were also identified in the product, suggesting that cyclohexene is an intermediate in the cyclohexane to benzene conversion. This identification was not possible during anisole HDO, probably due to the co-elution of cyclohexene with toluene on the GC column. To compare these results with those of anisole HDO, an experiment was conducted with anisole at 5 bar pressure, 160–270 °C, and WHSV 26 h−1. The hydrogen/feed ratio was maintained at 2570 (v/v), to achieve the same cyclohexane to hydrogen ratio at the reactor exit as compared to that during methoxycyclohexane HDO. This ensured that the observed trends in composition were not due to a difference in reaction equilibrium conditions as the equilibrium is governed by the excess of hydrogen with respect to the feed. This resulted in almost similar anisole conversion as compared to that with an H2/anisole volume ratio of 1660/1. When methoxycyclohexane selectivity in anisole HDO was compared with the conversion of methoxycyclohexane HDO (Fig. 11 a), it was found to be almost mirror image of each other, suggesting that the pathway of anisole HDO through ring hydrogenation is the primary one; even at temperatures greater than 220 °C, where only traces of methoxycyclohexane were seen in the product. The molar yields of benzene were found to be similar in both these experiments (Fig. 11 b), suggesting that benzene originates only from the dehydrogenation of cyclohexane, rather than by direct demethoxylation of anisole. Fig. 11 c shows that the molar ratio of benzene to cyclohexane in the product was equal in both these experiments. When this ratio is compared with that theoretically calculated with a stoichiometric amount of hydrogen and with the amount of hydrogen as used in the experiment, it was found to be closer to the former. This shows that the equilibrium distribution of products are mainly dependent on the availability of surface hydrogen rather than that in the bulk gas phase. The excess hydrogen in the bulk gas phase is necessary to obtain a similar amount of surface hydrogen in both these experiments. Furthermore, section S3 shows the possibility of dehydrogenation of cyclohexane to cyclohexene and benzene during the adsorption process of cyclohexane. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 11 d, cyclohexanol formation was not observed during methoxycyclohexane HDO over Ni/Al2O3 catalysts (for the entire range of methoxycyclohexane conversion, 2–98 % as indicated in Fig. 11 a), suggesting that methoxycyclohexane undergoes direct demethoxylation followed by hydrogenation to cyclohexane (via cyclohexene intermediate as indicated by the adsorption studies in section S3), but not demethylation yielding cyclohexanol. This is also in agreement with the adsorption studies of methoxycyclohexane (See Section S3). Where, cyclohexanol was not detected during the adsorption and hydrogenation of methoxycyclohexane; and the major product of methoxycyclohexane reactive adsorption ( Figure S8 a and b) were cyclohexene and benzene, along with methanol and methane. Previously described anisole adsorption studies (see section 3.2 ), have shown that demethylation reaction occurs during reactive adsorption of anisole, irrespective of the presence of hydrogen. Therefore, in the absence of an aromatic ring in methoxycyclohexane, such reactions were not possible. In section 3.2 TPSR study has shown that in the absence of reactive adsorption, anisole deoxygenation occurs mainly by demethoxylation in the presence of H2. This explains why methoxycyclohexane undergoes direct demethoxylation to cyclohexane, rather than demethylation to cyclohexanol. It may be interesting to note that reactive adsorption of methoxycyclohexane results in demethoxylation to cyclohexene (see section S3) which signifies that the adsorption of methoxycyclohexane is different from that of anisole. As a result, cyclohexanol may only originate from hydrogenation of phenol which is a product of the demethylation pathway of anisole. The work of Popov et al. [42] has shown that anisole is adsorbed on Al2O3 as a coordinated species at ambient temperatures. These adsorbed species then undergo demethylation at higher temperatures to afford adsorbed phenate and methoxy species. Also, as shown in Fig. 11 d, when a higher H2 flow rate (H2/anisole volume ratio) was used, the contact time of H2 decreased (i.e., the linear velocity of H2 increased). As a result, the demethylation route of anisole consumption was kinetically favored with respect to the ring hydrogenation pathway. This resulted in higher values of cyclohexanol selectivity as compared to those found with lower hydrogen flow rates. Fig. 12 , shows the result of HDO of phenol and cyclohexanol over 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, at 5 bar pressure, 270 °C, and WHSV 120 h−1. In these experiments, 2 wt% solutions each of phenol and cyclohexanol in decalin were used as the feedstocks. The inert nature of decalin was confirmed by a blank experiment. This was intended to simulate the concentration of phenol/cyclohexanol in the products of anisole HDO at WHSV 120 h−1 (discussed in section 3.3.3 ) with only phenol/cyclohexanol in an inert solvent. Fig. 12 a shows that about 70 % of phenol is converted primarily to cyclohexane, benzene, and condensation products under the given reaction conditions. Traces of cyclohexanol and cyclohexene were also seen, with selectivity of 1.5 % and 0.8 % respectively. Since there is a higher molar ratio of H2/reactant (400) as compared to that in the previous experiments (8 and 12), the product distribution shows a lower benzene/cyclohexane ratio. The study on phenol HDO over Ni/HZSM-5 and Ni/Al2O3-HZSM-5 catalysts at 50 bar pressure in a batch reactor, has also identified similar reaction intermediates with cyclohexane as the major product [49]. During cyclohexanol HDO, the major products were cyclohexane, cyclohexene, and cyclohexyl-cyclohexane (condensation reaction product). A trace amount of benzene was detected as shown in Fig. 12 b. Higher selectivity towards cyclohexene during cyclohexanol HDO further signifies the role played by the amount of surface hydrogen. In the case of phenol HDO, more hydrogen was consumed to saturate the aromatic ring, as a result, the reaction equilibrium was shifted more towards benzene. However, in cyclohexanol HDO due to lesser hydrogen consumption (and thus higher surface hydrogen availability) the equilibrium is shifted towards cyclohexene and cyclohexane. Also, as seen in Fig. 12 b, cyclohexanol was not completely converted (its maximum conversion was about 92 %) during a dedicated HDO experiment. This indicates that cyclohexanol is not formed as an intermediate of methoxycyclohexane HDO, otherwise it would have been detected especially at lower conversion of methoxycyclohexane. Thermodynamic calculation in section S6 has shown that cyclohexanol can be dehydrogenated to phenol under the experimental conditions used in our study ( Figure S13 b). However, the lack of phenol in the product suggests that the dehydration of cyclohexanol to cyclohexene (followed by its hydrogenation to cyclohexane) is faster than the dehydrogenation reaction. This agrees well with the discussions on thermodynamic equilibrium provided in section S6, where Figure S14 b shows that when water is considered as a product component, cyclohexane and benzene are the thermodynamically favored products of cyclohexanol deoxygenation. Direct deoxygenation of phenol to benzene has been reported over catalysts with lower hydrogenation power like FeMoP [50], and also in the case of unsupported NiP2 [51]. However, these articles also state that in the case of catalysts with higher selectivity towards ring hydrogenation (e.g., NiMoP) [50] and supported catalysts [51], the primary reaction of phenol HDO is ring hydrogenation to cyclohexanol, followed by deoxygenation to cyclohexane. 3.4 Reaction pathway Anisole is primarily adsorbed on the acidic sites of Al2O3 forming coordinated surface species. The adsorption process is reactive in nature and results in the demethylation of anisole to phenol, with methylation of the aromatic ring to methyl anisole/methyl phenol. However, these surface reactions require higher temperatures. While testing the catalyst at 5 bar H2 pressure, (de)methylation was seen at temperatures above 200 °C. The surface methoxy group was also found to be hydrogenated to C1-C4 alkanes due to higher hydrogen pressure (5–40 bar), in contrast to methylating the aromatic ring as observed in adsorption studies conducted at 0.1 bar H2 partial pressure ( section 3.2 ). However, at a higher temperature (>260 °C) methylation of the aromatic ring was observed at 5 bar when there was sufficient consumption of anisole by demethylation. These methylated un-deoxygenated molecules undergo further ring hydrogenation. They also undergo deoxygenation through demethoxylation and dehydration as shown in Fig. 13 . With higher reaction pressure (5–40 bar), ring-hydrogenation to methoxycyclohexane was found to be the predominant reaction. At temperatures below 200 °C, the adsorption process is almost non-reactive (see section 3.2 , Table 4 ) and anisole is consumed only through the ring hydrogenation. However, above 200 °C, reactive adsorption starts. Still, under this condition, ring hydrogenation is found to be the dominant reaction (as seen in section 3.3.4 ), possibly due to its higher rate as compared to reactive adsorption. Methoxycyclohexane formed from ring-hydrogenation of anisole undergoes demethoxylation directly to cyclohexene, for temperatures above 180 °C. Cyclohexene or cyclohexane formed by its facile hydrogenation then undergo dehydrogenation at temperatures above 220 °C to form benzene. The final products cyclohexane, cyclohexene and benzene remain in equilibrium depending on temperature, and availability of surface hydrogen (function of H2 pressure).Deoxygenation in an H2 environment, through demethoxylation in the absence of reactive adsorption, was also observed in section 3.2 . However, when comparing reaction product distribution for 20 and 40 bar with that for 5 bar, it was found that the cleavage of the O-cyclohexyl bond is preferred at lower H2 pressure. This is due to thermodynamics (Le Chatelier's principle) where the direction of reaction resulting in a larger number of molecules is favored at lower pressure. 4 Conclusions Studies on the reaction pathways in anisole HDO over Ni/Al2O3 are important for understanding the temperature–pressure dependence and the role of catalyst active sites that are decisive for the deoxygenation of lignin-derived phenolic compounds. In this article, a model HDO catalyst, 10 wt% Ni/Al2O3, was prepared by wet-impregnation method. The catalyst was characterized using XRF, ICPOES, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, H2 and NH3-TPD, and H2 pulse chemisorption. Based on these, interactions between Ni and Al2O3 support were described. Adsorption studies have shown that anisole is adsorbed on the acidic sites of the alumina supports. This adsorption turns into reactive adsorption at higher temperatures. Thus, during HDO reactions at H2 pressure greater than 5 bar and above 200 °C, two competing routes i.e., ring hydrogenation and (de)methylation were seen. The first is governed by the Ni sites in the presence of H2, while the latter occurs during the adsorption on Al2O3 irrespective of H2 availability. Although they are independent, they compete for anisole, i.e. the final product distribution is determined by the process parameters. At lower pressure (5–12 bar), the maximum anisole conversion is determined by the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation equilibrium. Deoxygenation through demethoxylation (methoxycyclohexane to cyclohexene/cyclohexane) was found to be prominent only above 180 °C. Dehydrogenation of cyclohexane to benzene occurs at temperatures above 220 °C. Reactive adsorption of anisole results in demethylation of anisole to phenol. The prominence of this reaction grew at temperatures above 200 °C. Above 260 °C, methylation of the aromatic ring occurs along with the demethylation reaction. At higher pressure (20–40 bar), anisole is converted almost solely through ring hydrogenation. This is primarily because aromatic ring hydrogenation occurs at a much faster rate than de(methylation) reactions, which are prominently observed only at high temperatures. It was also found that although the presence of H2 is essential for demethoxylation to take place, lower pressures favor the extent of this reaction route. The significance of deciphering two independent pathways (ring hydrogenation and (de)methylation of anisole) also opens up the opportunity of exploring the two reactions individually. The (de)methylation reactions may be selectively conducted with catalysts having low hydrogenation strength and at lower hydrogen pressure. The ring hydrogenation pathway may be selectively conducted at higher pressures and over catalysts with a high hydrogenation strength. coredata.dc:description: Anisole is a model molecule for studying hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin-derived oxygenates. Here we elucidate its HDO pathway over 10 % Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Adsorption experiments showed that anisole is adsorbed on the acidic sites of the Al2O3. Anisole adsorption at 200–300 °C is reactive in nature, and results in its demethylation. The catalyst was tested at 100–300 °C, 5–40 bar H2 pressure. Conversion of 78 % was obtained at 5 bar and 300 °C, restricted by hydrogenation-dehydrogenation equilibrium. HDO mainly starts through the ring-hydrogenation pathway. This is followed by demethoxylation beyond 180 °C. At 5–12 bar, cyclohexane dehydrogenates to benzene. This was confirmed by conducting an HDO experiment with methoxycyclohexane. At lower pressure deoxygenation is favored; and demethylation is accompanied with methylation of the aromatic ring, for temperature >260 °C. Investigation of the initial reaction stages showed that anisole HDO on Ni/Al2O3 catalyst proceeds via two independent pathways i.e., reactive adsorption/(de)methylation and aromatic ring hydrogenation.
